14#ifndef ISC_HASH_H
15#define ISC_HASH_H 1
16
17#include <inttypes.h>
18#include <stdbool.h>
19
20#include "isc/lang.h"
21#include "isc/types.h"
22
23/***
24 *** Functions
25 ***/
26ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
27
28const void *
29isc_hash_get_initializer(void);
30
31void
32isc_hash_set_initializer(const void *initializer);
33
34uint32_t
35isc_hash_function(const void *data, size_t length,
36 bool case_sensitive,
37 const uint32_t *previous_hashp);
38uint32_t
39isc_hash_function_reverse(const void *data, size_t length,
40 bool case_sensitive,
41 const uint32_t *previous_hashp);
42/*!<
43 * \brief Calculate a hash over data.
44 *
45 * This hash function is useful for hashtables. The hash function is
46 * opaque and not important to the caller. The returned hash values are
47 * non-deterministic and will have different mapping every time a
48 * process using this library is run, but will have uniform
49 * distribution.
50 *
51 * isc_hash_function() calculates the hash from start to end over the
52 * input data. isc_hash_function_reverse() calculates the hash from the
53 * end to the start over the input data. The difference in order is
54 * useful in incremental hashing; for example, a previously hashed
55 * value for 'com' can be used as input when hashing 'example.com'.
56 *
57 * 'data' is the data to be hashed.
58 *
59 * 'length' is the size of the data to be hashed.
60 *
61 * 'case_sensitive' specifies whether the hash key should be treated as
62 * case_sensitive values. It should typically be false if the hash key
63 * is a DNS name.
64 *
65 * 'previous_hashp' is a pointer to a previous hash value returned by
66 * this function. It can be used to perform incremental hashing. NULL
67 * must be passed during first calls.
68 */
69
70ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
71
72#endif /* ISC_HASH_H */
73
